1.question: Which of the following is NOT a stated learning outcome for 'Map Data Visualization (Part 2)'?

options.A: To develop advanced GIS programming skills
options.B: To describe spatial data for geographical visualization
options.C: To understand how to map qualitative and quantitative data
options.D: To apply interactive map data visualizations

2.question: According to the document, which two elements are considered fundamental requirements for map cosmetic?

options.A: Title and Legend

3.question: What is the primary purpose of a map legend?

options.A: To understand how the map topic is depicted
options.B: To show the map projection used

4.question: Which of the following is NOT listed as additional marginal information for map cosmetic?

options.A: North arrow

5.question: What information does 'lineage information' typically include in map marginalia?

options.A: Political boundaries and demographic data
options.B: Data sources, dates of data collection, and methods
options.C: Historical context of the mapped area
options.D: Map's color palette and font style

6.question: Why might on-screen maps often present legends and titles on demand?

options.A: To make maps more challenging to read

7.question: What is the 'keyword' for making maps visually appealing and increasing their communicative role, according to the document?

options.A: Contrast

8.question: What is the purpose of applying visual hierarchy to a map?

options.A: To ensure all information is equally weighted
options.B: To make the map appear more complex
options.C: To increase the communicative role by highlighting important information
options.D: To minimize the need for a legend

options.A: A map where colored or shaded areas represent the magnitude of an attribute
options.B: A map using only symbols and lines
options.C: A map used exclusively for navigation
options.D: A map showing only elevation changes

10.question: For what purpose are choropleth maps primarily created?

options.A: To compare the sizes of countries
options.D: To display variables' overall geographic patterns and compare spatial distribution changes

11.question: In a choropleth map, how would states with lower population density typically be shaded compared to those with higher density?

options.A: With a lighter gray color

12.question: Which type of data is generally considered inappropriate for choropleth maps?

options.A: Percentage of land covered by forest per region
options.C: Continuous data not controlled by an enumeration unit

13.question: What type of map projection is most appropriate for choropleth maps?

options.A: Equal area map projections

14.question: In choropleth map symbolization, which color is typically reserved for the background or outlines?

options.A: Light gray

15.question: What is the primary reason for data classification in choropleth mapping?

options.A: To hide certain data points
options.B: To simplify generalized data for display on the map
options.D: To make the map look more artistic

16.question: Which characteristic is typical of 'On-Screen Maps' according to the document?

options.A: They are often smaller than maps on paper and can link to tabular data
options.B: They are primarily designed for physical printing
options.C: They integrate photography, sound, and video

17.question: What is a distinguishing feature of a 'Multimedia Map'?

options.A: It requires Virtual Reality Markup Language (VRML) for viewing
options.B: It integrates photography, sound, video, and animation
options.C: It only provides a preview of available products
options.D: It is static and cannot be zoomed

18.question: What functionality is characteristic of 'Dynamic Maps'?

options.A: Zooming, panning, or hyperlinking other information, and user-chosen data layers
options.B: Only map view is available without interaction
options.D: Integration of sound and video for exploration

19.question: An interactive map is described as providing what kind of experience?

options.A: A fully interactive presentation of 3D models
options.D: A printed map for wide accessibility

20.question: What is a traditional role of the World Wide Web in relation to spatial data?

options.A: To collect raw GPS data
options.C: To show the location of objects and provide insights into spatial patterns

21.question: How do Geo-webservices contribute to interactive map views?

options.A: By standardizing physical map production
options.B: By acting as an intermediate between data and web browser
